Award.AwardTitle: Dynamical Influences on Stratocumulus-Aerosol Interactions in the Southern Hemisphere
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project has the following goals: (i) to undertake the analysis the Variability of the American Monsoon Systems (VAMOS) Ocean-Coupled-Atmosphere-Land-System (VOCALS) datasets; and (ii)to assess aerosol-cloud interactions for the southeast Atlantic and the dynamics that affect them. Precipitation impacts on aerosol indirect effects will be examined using remotely-sensed airborne VOCALS datasets and satellite-derived values. Aerosol transport pathways, their influence on and interactions with the southeast Atlantic stratocumulus deck at synoptic and diurnal time scales will also be examined, using a suite of observational datasets and reanalyses encompassing multiple years. A combination of approaches (empirical orthogonal functions, compositing, and backtrajectories and Lagrangian particle dispersion modeling) will be utilized.

This project will improve understanding the dynamical influences on aerosol-cloud interactions in the Southern Hemisphere. This has the potential to improve the capability of future climate predictions; thus this activity has substantial broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has focused on understanding the dynamics accompanying the aerosol and low distributions of the southeast Atlantic. This region is unique within the globe, in that an extensive layer of biomass-burning aerosol, emanating from fires on continental Africa, exists over one of the largest subtropical low cloud decks on the globe. Because the aerosol is capable of absorbing sunlight, and so do multiple times as the sunlight is bounced off of the lower clouds, the smoke in this region has the affect of warming the climate. In so doing, it is thought to affect regional precipitation patterns. The contribution of this award has been to a) characterize the remote southeast Atlantic environment using radiosondes, satellite and reanalysis datasets, b) better articulate the dynamics driving the smoke off of the continent, including a southerly African easterly jet, and c) characterize the synoptic variability of the low cloud deck and articulate the influence of the aerosol separately from other large-scale factors. These findings are summarized in three peer-reviewed publicatons. In terms of Broader Impacts, the award supported the PhD training of a student, and the involvement of the PI with a US Clivar Working Group on Eastern Tropical Ocean SST biases.
